    Project Object and Define Document

    Kyle Baron

    2018-11-03

    project.Rmd

    Introduction

    This vignette shows you how to gather the specifications for all of your analysis project data sets, assemble into a single object, and use that object to render a project-wide define document.

    Set up

    library(yspec)

    Load specifiation objects for all data sets

    If my project had 3 analysis data sets, one for PK, one for PKPD, and one for AEs, we create a specification object for each one. Here, we’re using load_spec_ex() because we’re using example material from the package. You should use load_spec() for your project.

    sp1 <- load_spec_ex("DEM104101F_PK.yml")
sp2 <- load_spec_ex("DEM104101F_PKPD.yml")
sp3 <- load_spec_ex("DEM104101F_AE.yml")

    So each object looks something like

    sp1
    ##  col name    type      unit short  
##  1   C       character .    C      
##  2   USUBJID character .    USUBJID
##  3   ID      character .    ID     
##  4   EVID    numeric   .    EVID   
##  5   WT      numeric   .    WT

    So this includes our usual information about the columns in the data set.

    Create a project object

    We take these specification objects and create a project object from them.

    proj <- as_proj_spec(sp1,sp2,sp3)
    ## Writing project file to:
## file16f5a3d003d3d.yml in tempdir()
    proj
    ##  name            description                      
##  DEM104101F_PK   Population PK analysis data set  
##  DEM104101F_PKPD Population PKPD analysis data set
##  DEM104101F_AE   AE analysis data set

    Now, for each specification object, we have a data / specification name as well as a description (along with some other information).

    This file is by default saved to a temporary location. But you can also save it locally and keep it as a part of the project.

    # Generated by yspec::as_proj_spec; do not edit by hand
# Sat Nov  3 11:33:46 2018
SETUP__:
  sponsor: ABC Pharmaceuticals, Inc
  projectnumber: DEM104101F
  yml_file: /var/folders/xb/hqmfzgl95fq8mx6tjxkzb71r0000gn/T//RtmpItPctr/file16f5a3d003d3d.yml
  path: /var/folders/xb/hqmfzgl95fq8mx6tjxkzb71r0000gn/T//RtmpItPctr
  data_path: data/derived
DEM104101F_PK:
  data_path: data/derived
  data_file: DEM104101F_PK.xpt
  spec_path: /Users/kyleb/ghe/software/yspec/vignettes
  spec_file: /Users/kyleb/Rlibs/yspec/spec/DEM104101F_PK.yml
  description: Population PK analysis data set
  name: DEM104101F_PK
DEM104101F_PKPD:
  data_path: data/derived
  data_file: DEM104101F_PKPD.xpt
  spec_path: /Users/kyleb/ghe/software/yspec/vignettes
  spec_file: /Users/kyleb/Rlibs/yspec/spec/DEM104101F_PKPD.yml
  description: Population PKPD analysis data set
  name: DEM104101F_PKPD
DEM104101F_AE:
  data_path: data/derived
  data_file: DEM104101F_AE.xpt
  spec_path: /Users/kyleb/ghe/software/yspec/vignettes
  spec_file: /Users/kyleb/Rlibs/yspec/spec/DEM104101F_AE.yml
  description: AE analysis data set
  name: DEM104101F_AE

    To do this, we tucked some additional information into the data set specification file

    str(get_meta(sp1))
    ## List of 9
##  $ lookup_file  : chr [1:2] "/Users/kyleb/Rlibs/yspec/spec/_yspec_lookup.yml" "/Users/kyleb/Rlibs/yspec/spec/_yspec_lookup.yml"
##  $ projectnumber: chr "DEM104101F"
##  $ sponsor      : chr "ABC Pharmaceuticals, Inc"
##  $ description  : chr "Population PK analysis data set"
##  $ data_path    : chr "data/derived"
##  $ yml_file     : chr "/Users/kyleb/Rlibs/yspec/spec/DEM104101F_PK.yml"
##  $ path         : chr "/Users/kyleb/Rlibs/yspec/spec"
##  $ name         : chr "DEM104101F_PK"
##  $ primary_key  : chr(0)

    In the SETUP__ block, we included a description; this is required to make a project object from data objects. There also is a name that defaults to the stem of the data specification file. We also optionally included projectnumber and sponsor. These will get inserted into the define documentwhen the MetrumRG Rmarkdown template is used.

    Render a define file

    Now, we have an object with the project information put together. The essential contents of that object have been written to a project spec file and can be used to template the creation of a project data specification file.

    render_define(proj, stem = "define_doc")

    Contents

    • Load specifiation objects for all data sets
    • Create a project object
